# A Proof of Theorem 1
## A. 1 Proof of Theorem 1 (i)

Lemmas 1 to 3 prove slightly more general results than the ones we refer to in the proof sketch (Section 2.4), as those results are also used in the proof of Theorem 2.

Lemma 1. For any regulation $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$,

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C}) \geq \sup _{0 \leq y \leq \bar{y}} \alpha \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)
$$

Proof. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$. Suppose that the production set $\mathcal{A}$ contains a single action producing the output level $0 \leq y^{\prime} \leq \bar{y}$ with probability 1 at zero cost, $\mathcal{A}=\left\{\left(0, \delta_{\left\{y^{\prime}\right\}}\right)\right\}$, and that the operational cost $k$ is such that $0 \leq k<y^{\prime}$. Given the technology $\mathcal{T}=(k, \mathcal{A})$ and the regulation $\mathcal{C}$, the maximal profit the firm can obtain is

$$
y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)-k
$$

where $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)=\inf \left\{w\left(y^{\prime}\right): w \in \mathcal{C}_{0}\right\}$. If $k>y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)$, no contract is signed between the firm and the worker, as the firm strictly prefers her outside option to the best available contract in $\mathcal{C}$. The regret for the regulator is then

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-k\right)
$$

since contract $w^{R}$ such that $w^{R}(y)=(y-k) \mathbb{1}_{\left\{y^{\prime}=y\right\}}$ implements action $\left(0, \delta_{\left\{y^{\prime}\right\}}\right)$ and allocates the entire surplus to the worker. Taking the supremum over $k \in\left[0, y^{\prime}-\right.$ $\left.\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)$, we obtain

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C}) \geq \alpha \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)
$$

Finally, we obtain the bound in Lemma 1 by taking the supremum over $0 \leq y^{\prime} \leq$ $\bar{y}$.

Lemma 2. For any regulation $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$,

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C}) \geq \alpha \sup _{0 \leq y \leq \bar{y}} e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)-y}{y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)}}\left(y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)\right) \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y) \leq \frac{1}{2} y\right\}}
$$

Proof. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$. For all $0 \leq y \leq \bar{y}$, define $\underline{w}^{C}(y)=\inf \{w(y): w \in \mathcal{C}\}$ and $\mathcal{Y}^{I C}=$ $\left\{y \in \mathcal{Y}: \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y) \leq \frac{1}{2} y\right\}$. If $\mathcal{Y}^{I C}=\emptyset$, we are done since, by definition, the regret is non negative. So, suppose that $\mathcal{Y}^{I C} \neq \emptyset$, and let $y^{\prime} \in \mathcal{Y}^{I C}$.

Let the operational cost $k$ be (strictly) smaller than $y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)$. Denote by $B_{i}$ the binary output distribution with support $\left\{0, y^{\prime}\right\}$ and mean $i$. Define $\underline{i}=y^{\prime} \frac{k}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}$ and the production set $\mathcal{A}^{k}$ as

$$
\mathcal{A}^{k}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right): i \in I=\left[\underline{i}, y^{\prime}\right]\right\}
$$

where, for all $i \in I$,

$$
e_{i}=i-\frac{k y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}+k\left(\ln \left(\frac{k y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}\right)-\ln (i)\right)
$$

For all $0 \leq k<y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)$, the distributions $B_{i}, i \in I$, are supported on $\left\{0, y^{\prime}\right\}$. Thus, $\mathcal{A}^{k}$ is compact and satisfies Assumptions 1 and 2.

By definition of $e_{i}$, for all $w \in \mathcal{C}$,

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial i}\left(\ell^{w} i-e_{i}\right)=\ell^{w}-\frac{i-k}{i} \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow \ell^{w} \geq \frac{i-k}{i}
$$

where $\ell^{w}=\frac{w\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}$. So, for $\underline{i}<i<y^{\prime},\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$ if and only if

$$
w\left(y^{\prime}\right)=\frac{i-k}{i} y^{\prime}
$$

Action $\underline{i}$ is only implementatble by $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}$, and action $i=y^{\prime}$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$

if and only if

$$
w\left(y^{\prime}\right) \geq \frac{y^{\prime}-k}{y^{\prime}} y^{\prime}
$$

Next, observe that, for all $i \in[\underline{i}, y^{\prime}]$, any contract that implements $\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ gives a profit of at most zero to the principal. As a result, any contract that implements $\left(e_{y^{\prime}}, B_{y^{\prime}}\right)$ is a regulator's preferred contract. They maximise the total surplus, since $\frac{\partial}{\partial t} e_{i} \leq 1$, and allocate all of it to the worker:

$$
V(\mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-k-e_{y^{\prime}}\right)
$$

However, since no contract gives the firm a strictly positive payoff, in the worst-case scenario for the regulator, the firm chooses her outside option. The regulator's regret is then

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=V(\mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-k-e_{y^{\prime}}\right)
$$

Plugging in the effort cost, the regret is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-k-e_{y^{\prime}}\right) & =\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-k-y^{\prime}+\frac{k y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}-k\left(\ln \left(\frac{k y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}\right)-\ln \left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)\right) \\
& =\alpha k\left(\frac{y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}-\ln \left(\frac{k}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}\right)-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the worst-case regret is obtained by maximizing over all possible technologies, we can obtain a lower bound by taking the supremum of the above expression with respect to $k \in\left[0, y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{C}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)$. Since the function $k \rightarrow \alpha\left(y^{\prime}-k-e_{y^{\prime}}\right)$ is continuous on $\left[0, y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right]$, its supremum over $k \in\left[0, y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)$ is equal its maximum over

$k \in\left[0, y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right]$. Taking derivatives with respect to $k$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial}{\partial k}\left(\alpha k\left(\frac{y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}-\ln \left(\frac{k}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}\right)-1\right)\right) \geq 0 \\
\Leftrightarrow & \frac{y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}-\ln \left(\frac{k}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}\right)-2 \geq 0 \\
\Leftrightarrow & k \leq e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)-y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}}\left(y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

So, $\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-k-e_{y^{\prime}}\right)$ is maximised over $k \in\left[0, y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right]$ at

$$
k=e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)-y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}}\left(y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)
$$

It follows that the regulator's worst-case regret is bounded below by

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C})=\sup _{\mathcal{T}} R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}) \geq \sup _{k \in\left[0, y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)} R\left(\mathcal{C},\left(k, \mathcal{A}^{k}\right)\right)=\alpha e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)-y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}}\left(y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{C}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)
$$

Since $y^{\prime} \in \mathcal{Y}^{I C}$ was arbitrary, the lower bound in Lemma 2 follows.
Lemma 3. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$. For all $y \geq 0$, define $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)=\inf \{w(y): w \in \mathcal{C}\}$. Then

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C}) \geq \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}} \sup _{0 \leq y \leq \bar{y}}\left(y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)\right)
$$

Proof. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$. For all $y \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$, define $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)=\inf \{w(y): w \in \mathcal{C}\}$. Let $0 \leq \mu_{F} \leq$ $y^{\prime} \leq \bar{y}$ and $\Pi=\left(1-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}\right) \mu_{F}$. Denote by $B_{i}$ the binary output distribution with support $\left\{0, y^{\prime}\right\}$ and mean $i$. Define the production set $\mathcal{A}^{\Pi}$ as

$$
\mathcal{A}^{\mu_{F}}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right): i \in I=\left[\mu_{F}, y^{\prime}\right]\right\}
$$

where, for all $i \in I$,

$$
e_{i}=i-\mu_{F}+\Pi\left(\ln \left(\mu_{F}\right)-\ln i\right)+\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \mu_{F}
$$

We consider the technology $\mathcal{T}=\left(0, \mathcal{A}^{\mu_{F}}\right)$, i.e., we assume that the firm has no operational cost. For all $0 \leq \mu_{F} \leq y^{\prime}$, the distributions $F_{i}, i \in I$, are supported on $\left\{0, y^{\prime}\right\}$. Thus, $\mathcal{A}^{k}$ is compact and satisfies Assumptions 1 and 2.

By definition of $e_{i}$, for all $w \in \mathcal{C}$,

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial i}\left(\ell^{w} i-e_{i}\right)=\ell^{w}-\frac{i-\Pi}{i} \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow \ell^{w} \geq \frac{i-\Pi}{i}
$$

where $\ell^{w}=\frac{w\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}$. So, $\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ with $i<y^{\prime}$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$ if and only if

$$
w\left(y^{\prime}\right)=\frac{i-\Pi}{i} y^{\prime}
$$

while action $i=y^{\prime}$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$ if and only if

$$
w\left(y^{\prime}\right) \geq \frac{y^{\prime}-\Pi}{y^{\prime}} y^{\prime}
$$

Next, observe that, for all $i$, any contract that implements $\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ gives a profit of at most $\Pi$ to the principal, and exactly $\Pi$ if the inequality holds with equality, since

$$
\left(1-\frac{i-\Pi}{i}\right) \mathbb{E}_{B_{i}}[y]=\Pi
$$

Moreover, the contract $w(y)=y$ implements the surplus maximizing action $\left(e_{y^{\prime}}, B_{y^{\prime}}\right)$ (since $\frac{\partial}{\partial i} e_{i} \leq 1$ ), and leaves no profit to the firm, hence allocating the entire surplus to the worker. So, it is the regulator's preferred contract.

$$
V(\mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-e_{y^{\prime}}\right)
$$

Since no contract gives the firm a strictly higher profit than $\Pi$, in the worst-case scenario, she decides to implement the least productive action, generating the average

output $\mu_{F}$. The regulator's regret is then

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=V(\mathcal{T})-(\Pi(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})+\alpha W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}))=\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-e_{y^{\prime}}-\left(\mu_{F}-e_{\mu_{F}}\right)\right)+(\alpha-1) \Pi
$$

Plugging in the effort cost, the regret is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-e_{y^{\prime}}-\left(\mu_{F}-e_{\mu_{F}}\right)\right)+(\alpha-1) \Pi & =-\alpha \Pi\left(\ln \left(\mu_{F}\right)-\ln y^{\prime}\right)+(\alpha-1) \Pi \\
& =\alpha \int_{\mu_{F}}^{y^{\prime}} \frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu} \mu_{F} d \mu+(\alpha-1)\left(1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}\right) \mu_{F}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the worst-case regret is obtained by maximising over all possible technologies, we can obtain a lower bound by taking the supremum of the above expression with respect to $\mu_{F} \in\left[0, y^{\prime}\right]$, which is achieved for $\mu_{F}=y^{\prime} e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}$. It follows that the regulator's worst-case regret is bounded below by

$$
\begin{aligned}
W C R(\mathcal{C})=\sup _{\mathcal{T}} R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}) & \geq \sup _{\mu_{F} \in\left[0, y^{\prime}\right]} R\left(\mathcal{C},\left(0, \mathcal{A}^{\mu_{F}}\right)\right) \\
& =\alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $y^{\prime}$ was arbitrary, the lower bound in Lemma 3 follows.
Proof of Theorem 1 (i). By Lemmas 1 to 3, for all $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}, W C R(\mathcal{C})$ is bounded below by

$$
\sup _{0 \leq y \leq \bar{y}} \max \left\{\alpha \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y), \alpha e^{\frac{2 w^{\mathcal{C}}(y)-y}{y-w^{\mathcal{C}}(y)}}\left(y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)\right) \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y) \leq \frac{1}{2} y\right\}}, \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)\right)\right\}
$$

which is bounded below by the function whose supremum is taken, evaluated at $\bar{y}$,

$$
\max \left\{\alpha \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y}), \alpha e^{\frac{2 w^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})-\bar{y}}{y-w^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})}}\left(\bar{y}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})\right) \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y}) \leq \frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right\}}, \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(\bar{y}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})\right)\right\}
$$

which itself is greater than

$$
\min _{0 \leq \underline{w} \leq \bar{y}} \max \left\{\alpha \underline{w}, \alpha e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w}) \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\underline{w} \leq \frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right\}}, \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w})\right\}
$$

Noting that $\underline{w}=e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w})$ when $\underline{w}=\frac{1}{2} \bar{y}$, Lemma 7 in the Online Appendix D. 1 establishes that this equals $\bar{R}$, hence showing Theorem 1 (i).

# A. 2 Proof of Theorem 1 (ii) 

To prove that $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}=\left\{w \in \mathcal{C}_{0}: w(y) \geq \frac{\alpha-1}{2 \alpha-1} y\right.$ for all $\left.y \geq 0\right\} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$ is optimal, we show that the associated regulator's worst-case regret is

$$
W C R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}\right) \leq \bar{R}
$$

Since $\bar{R}$ is a lower bound on the regulator's regret for any regulation $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$, the result then follows: 1) the regulation $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ is optimal, and 2) the worst-case regret is $\bar{R}$.

That Equation (10) holds follows from:

$$
\begin{aligned}
W C R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}\right) & =\sup _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{T}} R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) \\
& =\max \left\{\sup _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{T}: \Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=0} R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right), \sup _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{T}: \Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)>0} R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)\right\} \\
& \leq \max \left\{e^{\frac{2 \ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}-\bar{y}}{g-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}}}(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}), \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}\right)\right\} \\
& =\bar{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

where the inequality follows from Lemmas 4 and 5 below.
Lemma 4. The regulator's regret under regulation $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ is bounded above by

$$
\alpha e^{\frac{2 \ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}-\bar{y}}{g-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}}}(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y})=\bar{R}
$$

for all technologies $\mathcal{T}=(k, \mathcal{A})$ such that $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=0$

Proof. Let $\mathcal{T}=\left(k, \mathcal{A}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, F_{i}\right)\right\}_{i \in I}\right)$ be a technology such that $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=0$. For all $i \in I$, we write $\mu_{i}$ for $\mathbb{E}_{F_{i}}[y]$. Denote by $\left(e_{R}, F_{R}\right)$ the action implemented by the regulator under complete information (i.e., the action that solves $\left(R^{f u l l}\right)$ ). Since $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=0$, we can assume that the firm takes her outside option, as it maximises regret among all possible contracting equilibria. We distinguish two cases:
a) if $\mathbb{E}_{F_{R}}[y]=\mu_{R} \leq \frac{k}{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}$, we show that

$$
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) \leq \alpha \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}
$$

b) if $\mathbb{E}_{F_{R}}[y]=\mu_{R}>\frac{k}{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}$, we show that

$$
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) \leq \alpha e^{\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{l_{a}^{\star} \bar{y}-\bar{y}}-1}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)
$$

The claim then follows since

$$
\alpha \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y} \leq \alpha e^{\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{l_{a}^{\star} \bar{y}-\bar{y}}-1}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)=\bar{R}
$$

where the inequality is proved in point 2 of Lemma 7 in the Online Appendix D.1 . Start with case a).
a) If $\mu_{R} \leq \frac{k}{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}$, then

$$
\mu_{R}-k \leq \frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}} \mu_{R}
$$

Therefore, the regulator's regret is bounded above by

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) & \leq \alpha\left(\mu_{R}-e_{R}-k\right) \\
& \leq \alpha\left(\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}} \mu_{R}-e_{R}\right) \\
& \leq \alpha \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}
\end{aligned}
$$

b) If $\mu_{R}>\frac{k}{1-\frac{\alpha_{1} \cdot y}{y}}$, then

$$
\frac{\mu_{R}-k}{\mu_{R}}>\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}
$$

So, the linear contract $y \rightarrow \frac{\mu_{R}-k-\epsilon_{1}}{\mu_{R}} \cdot y$ belongs to the regulation $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ for $\epsilon_{1}>0$ small. Since $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=0$, there exists $i_{1} \in I$ such that

$$
\left(1-\frac{\mu_{R}-\epsilon_{1}-k}{\mu_{R}}\right) \mu_{i_{1}}-k \leq 0<\left(1-\frac{\mu_{R}-\epsilon_{1}-k}{\mu_{R}}\right) \mu_{R}-k \quad \Rightarrow \quad \mu_{i_{1}}<\mu_{R}
$$

and $^{27}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mu_{R}-\epsilon_{1}-k}{\mu_{R}} \mu_{i_{1}}-e_{i_{1}} \geq \frac{\mu_{R}-\epsilon_{1}-k}{\mu_{R}} \mu_{R}-e_{R} \\
\Longleftrightarrow & \left(e_{R}-e_{i_{1}}\right) \geq \frac{\mu_{R}-\epsilon_{1}-k}{\mu_{R}}\left(\mu_{R}-\mu_{i_{1}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

If there exists multiple such actions in $\mathcal{A}$, take $\left(e_{i_{1}}, F_{i_{1}}\right)$ to be the action with smallest mean that meet the above criteria. ${ }^{28}$ If $\mu_{i_{1}} \leq \frac{k}{1-\frac{\alpha^{\mu}(y)}{y}}$, we stop here. Otherwise, we proceed inductively, always selecting the smallest such action, to construct a sequence $\left\{i_{j}\right\}_{j \in \mathbb{N}}$ such that, for all $j \in \mathbb{N}, \mu_{i_{j+1}}<\mu_{i_{j}}, 0<\epsilon_{j+1} \leq \frac{1}{2} \epsilon_{j}$, and

$$
-\left(e_{i_{j}}-e_{i_{j+1}}\right) \leq-\left(1-\frac{k+\epsilon_{i_{j}}}{\mu_{i_{j}}}\right)\left(\mu_{i_{j}}-\mu_{i_{j+1}}\right)
$$

until we reach an action $\left(e_{i_{N}}, F_{i_{N}}\right)$ such that $\mu_{i_{N}} \leq \frac{k}{1-\frac{\alpha_{1} \cdot y}{y}}$. If no such $N \in \mathbb{N}$ exists, recall that, by Assumption 1, $\mathcal{A}$ is compact. So, passing to a subsequence and relabelling if necessary, the sequence converges to some action $\left(e_{i_{\infty}}, F_{i_{\infty}}\right) \in \mathcal{A}$ such that $\mu_{i_{\infty}}<\mu_{i_{j}}$ for all $j \in \mathbb{N}$.

    ${ }^{28}$ We can always find such action since $\mathcal{A}$ is compact by Assumption 1.

We claim that

$$
\mu_{i_{\infty}} \leq \frac{k}{1-\frac{\underline{\epsilon_{k} \cdot \bar{y}}}{\bar{y}}}
$$

Suppose not, for a contradiction. Then $\mu_{i_{\infty}}>\frac{k}{1-\frac{\epsilon_{k} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}$, and the linear contract $y \rightarrow$ $\frac{\mu_{i_{\infty}}-\epsilon_{\infty}-k}{\mu_{i_{\infty}}} \mu_{i_{\infty}} y$ belongs to $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ for $\epsilon_{\infty}>0$ small. Since $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=0$, there exists $i \in I$ such that

$$
\left(1-\frac{\mu_{i_{\infty}}-\epsilon_{\infty}-k}{\mu_{i_{\infty}}}\right) \mu_{i}-k \leq 0<\left(1-\frac{\mu_{i_{\infty}}-\epsilon_{\infty}-k}{\mu_{i_{\infty}}}\right) \mu_{i_{\infty}}-k \quad \Rightarrow \quad \mu_{i}<\mu_{\infty}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\mu_{i_{\infty}}-\epsilon_{\infty}-k}{\mu_{i_{\infty}}} \mu_{i}-e_{i}>\frac{\mu_{i_{\infty}}-\epsilon_{\infty}-k}{\mu_{i_{\infty}}} \mu_{i_{\infty}}-e_{i_{\infty}} \\
\Longleftrightarrow & e_{i_{\infty}}-e_{i}>\frac{\mu_{i_{\infty}}-\epsilon_{\infty}-k}{\mu_{i_{\infty}}}\left(\mu_{i}-\mu_{i_{\infty}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

So the sequence $\left(e_{i_{j}}, F_{i_{j}}\right)_{j \in \mathbb{N}}$ we constructed does not converge to $\left(e_{i_{\infty}}, F_{i_{\infty}}\right)$ : a contradiction. Therefore,

$$
\mu_{i_{\infty}} \leq \frac{k}{1-\frac{\underline{\epsilon_{k} \cdot \bar{y}}}{\bar{y}}}
$$

Summing the inequalities in Equation (12) over the $j^{\prime}$ s, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
-e_{R} \leq-e_{R}+e_{i_{\infty}} & =-\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\left(e_{i_{j}}-e_{i_{j+1}}\right) \\
& \leq \epsilon_{1}-\sum_{j=0}^{\infty}\left(1-\frac{k}{\mu_{i_{j}}}\right)\left(\mu_{i_{j}}-\mu_{i_{j+1}}\right) \\
& \leq \epsilon_{1}-\int_{\substack{1-\frac{k}{\mu_{i}}}}^{\mu_{R}}\left(1-\frac{k}{\mu}\right) d \mu
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\epsilon_{1}>0$ was arbitrary, it follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) & =\alpha\left(\mu_{R}-e_{R}-k\right) \\
& \leq \alpha\left(k \frac{\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y}}{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y}}-k\left(\ln \left(\frac{k}{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y}}\right)-\ln \left(\mu_{R}\right)\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The supremum of the upper bound in Equation (13) over $\mu_{R} \in[0, \bar{y}]$ and $k \in\left[0, \mu_{R}\left(1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y}\right)\right]$ is obtained for $\mu_{R}^{\star}=\bar{y}$ and

$$
k^{*}=e^{\frac{2 \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}-\bar{y}}{y-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}}(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y})
$$

It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) & \leq \alpha e^{\frac{2 \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}-\bar{y}}{y-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)\left(\frac{\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y}}{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y}}-\left(\ln \left(\frac{e^{\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}}-1}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)}{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}{y}}\right)-\ln (\bar{y})\right)\right) \\
& =\alpha e^{\frac{2 \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}-\bar{y}}{y-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \bar{y}}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This concludes the proof of Lemma 4.
Lemma 5. The regulator's regret under regulation $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ is bounded above by

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)=\bar{R}
$$

for all technologies $\mathcal{T}=(k, \mathcal{A})$ such that $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)>0$
Proof. Let $\mathcal{T}=\left(k, \mathcal{A}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, F_{i}\right)\right\}_{i \in I}\right)$ be a technology such that $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)>0$. For all $i \in I$, we write $\mu_{i}$ for $\mathbb{E}_{F_{i}}[y]$. Denote by $\left(e_{R}, F_{R}\right)$ the action implemented by the regulator under complete information (i.e., the action that solves $\left(R^{\text {full }}\right)$ ) and by $\left(e_{F}, F_{F}\right)$ the action optimally implemented by the firm. By Lemma 8, we can assume that (i) $k=0$, (ii) the firm optimally implements $\left(e_{F}, F_{F}\right)$ by offering the minimum linear contract $\ell_{\alpha}^{\star}$, and (iii) the worker's surplus $W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=\mathbb{E}_{F_{F}}\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right]-e_{F}$ is zero.

We show that

$$
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) \leq \max \left\{(\alpha-1)\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right), \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)\right\}
$$

Lemma 9 in the Online Appendix D. 1 shows that $(\alpha-1)\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right) \leq \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)$. Therefore, Lemma 5 follows from Equation (16).

To prove the inequality in Equation (16), first observe that the worker's incentive compatibility constraint $\left(I C_{W}\right)$ implies that, for all $(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{F}\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right]-e \leq \mathbb{E}_{F_{F}}\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right]-e_{F}=W S\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=0
$$

In particular,

$$
e_{R} \geq \mathbb{E}_{F_{R}}\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right]=\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \mu_{R}
$$

Since $k=0$, the total surplus is maximised by the $\left(R^{\text {full }}\right)$-optimal action $\left(e_{R}, F_{R}\right)-$ as the contract $y \mapsto y$ implements it. So, $\mu_{F}-e_{F} \leq \mu_{R}-e_{R}$. As a result, either a) $\mu_{R}-e_{R}=\mu_{F}-e_{F}$, or b) $\mu_{R}-e_{R}>\mu_{F}-e_{F}$. We treat the two cases a) and b) separately. a) Suppose that the action implemented by the firm maximises the total surplus: $\mu_{R}-e_{R}=\mu_{F}-e_{F}$. Equation (17) then implies that $\mu_{R}-e_{R} \leq \mu_{R}-\mathbb{E}_{F_{R}}\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right]=$ $\mathbb{E}_{F_{R}}\left[y-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right]$. The regulator's regret is then bounded above by

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) & \leq(\alpha-1)\left(\mu_{R}-e_{R}\right) \\
& =(\alpha-1) \mathbb{E}_{F_{R}}\left[y-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right] \\
& \leq(\alpha-1)\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality follows since $\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \leq 1$.
b) Suppose that the firm does not implement an efficient action: $\mu_{R}-e_{R}>\mu_{F}-e_{F}$.

Then $\mu_{F}<\mu_{R}$, since $e_{R} \geq \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \mu_{R}$ and $e_{F}=\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \mu_{F}$. The regulator's regret is

$$
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right)=\alpha\left(\mu_{R}-e_{R}\right)-\left(1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}\right) \mu_{F}
$$

# Claim: 

$$
e_{F}-e_{R} \leq-\int_{\mu_{F}}^{\mu_{F}}\left(1-\frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{L}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu} \mu_{F}\right) d \mu
$$

Proof of the Claim: For all $\mu>\mu_{F}$,

$$
1-\frac{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu} \mu_{F}>\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}
$$

Therefore $\mu_{R}>\mu_{F}$ implies that the linear contract

$$
y \mapsto\left(1-\epsilon_{R}-\frac{1-\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{R}} \mu_{F}\right) \cdot y
$$

belongs to the regulation $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ for $\epsilon_{R}>0$ small. Firm's optimality implies that offering this linear contract cannot increase the firm's profit. So, it cannot implement $\left(e_{R}, F_{R}\right)$, and there exists an action $\left(e_{1}, F_{1}\right) \in \mathcal{A}$ with $\mu_{1}<\mu_{R}$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(1-\epsilon_{R}-\frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{L}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{R}} \mu_{F}\right) \mu_{1}-e_{1}>\left(1-\epsilon_{R}-\frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{L}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{R}} \mu_{F}\right) \mu_{R}-e_{R} \\
\Leftrightarrow & e_{R}-e_{1}>\left(1-\epsilon_{R}-\frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{L}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{R}} \mu_{F}\right)\left(\mu_{R}-\mu_{1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\mu_{1} \leq \mu_{F}$, then the above also holds for the profit maximizing action $\left(e_{F}, \mu_{F}\right)$. In that case, choose $\left(e_{1}, F_{1}\right)=\left(e_{F}, F_{F}\right)$ and stop here. If, instead, $\mu_{1}>\mu_{F}$, we proceed

inductively. Since $\mu_{1}>\mu_{F}$, the linear contract

$$
y \mapsto\left(1-\epsilon_{1}-\frac{1-\frac{\rho_{1} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{1}} \mu_{F}\right) \cdot y
$$

belongs to the regulation $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{*}$ for $\frac{1}{2} \epsilon_{R} \geq \epsilon_{1}>0$ small. Firm's optimality implies that offering this linear contract cannot increase the firm's profit. So, there exists an action $\left(e_{2}, F_{2}\right) \in \mathcal{A}$ with $\mu_{2}<\mu_{1}$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(1-\epsilon_{1}-\frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{1}} \mu_{F}\right) \mu_{2}-e_{2}>\left(1-\epsilon_{1}-\frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{1}} \mu_{F}\right) \mu_{1}-e_{1} \\
\Leftrightarrow & e_{1}-e_{2}>\left(1-\epsilon_{1}-\frac{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{1}} \mu_{F}\right)\left(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

If $\mu_{1} \leq \mu_{F}$, then the above also holds for the profit maximizing action $\left(e_{F}, \mu_{F}\right)$. In that case, choose $\left(e_{1}, F_{1}\right)=\left(e_{F}, F_{F}\right)$ and stop here. If, instead, $\mu_{2}>\mu_{F}$, we continue our construction until we can choose $\left(e_{N}, F_{N}\right)=\left(e_{F}, F_{F}\right)$. So, we obtain a sequence $\left\{\left(e_{j}, F_{j}\right)\right\}_{0 \leq j \leq N \leq \infty}$, where $\left(e_{0}, F_{0}\right)=\left(e_{R}, F_{R}\right)$, such that, for all $1 \leq j \leq N-1, \mu_{j+1}<\mu_{j}$ and

$$
e_{j}-e_{j+1}>\left(1-\epsilon_{1}-\frac{1-\frac{\rho_{1} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{j}} \mu_{F}\right)\left(\mu_{j}-\mu_{j+1}\right)
$$

for some $0<\epsilon_{j}<\frac{1}{2} \epsilon_{j-1}$. If $N=\infty$, passing to a subsequence and relabeling if necessary, we can assume that the sequence $\left\{\left(e_{j}, F_{j}\right)\right\}_{0 \leq j \leq N=\infty}$ converges to some action $\left(e_{\infty}, F_{\infty}\right) \in \mathcal{A}$ with mean $\mu_{\infty}$ since $\mathcal{A}$ is compact by Assumption 1. By construction, $\mu_{F} \leq \mu_{\infty} \leq \mu_{j}$ for all $j \geq 0$.

We show that $\mu_{\infty}=\mu_{F}$. Suppose not for a contradiction. I.e., $\mu_{\infty}>\mu_{F}$. Then the linear contract

$$
y \rightarrow\left(1-\epsilon_{\infty}-\frac{1-\frac{\rho_{1} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{\infty}} \mu_{F}\right) \cdot y
$$

belongs to $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ for some $\epsilon_{\infty}>0$ small. So, there exists $m \in I$ such that $\mu_{m}<\mu_{\infty}$ and

$$
\left(1-\epsilon_{\infty}-\frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{\infty}} \mu_{F}\right) \mu_{m}-e_{m}>\left(1-\epsilon_{\infty}-\frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{i}} \mu_{P}\right) \mu_{\infty}-e_{\infty}
$$

But, then, the sequence $\left\{\left(e_{j}, F_{j}\right)\right\}_{0 \leq j \leq \infty}$ does not converge to $\left(e_{\infty}, F_{\infty}\right)$ : a contradiction. So, $\mu_{F}=\mu_{\infty}$.

Finally, for $\mu_{F}=\mu_{\infty}$, Equation (17) implies that $e_{F} \leq e_{\infty}$. So, $e_{F}-e_{R} \leq e_{\infty}-e_{R}$.
Multiplying the inequalities in Equation (19) by -1 and summing over the $j^{\prime}$ s, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
e_{F}-e_{R} & =\sum_{j=0}^{N}\left(e_{j+1}-e_{j}\right) \\
& \leq \epsilon_{R}\left(\mu_{R}-\mu_{F}\right)-\sum_{i=0}^{\infty}\left(1-\frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{i_{j}}} \mu_{F}\right)\left(\mu_{j}-\mu_{j+1}\right) \\
& =\epsilon_{R}\left(\mu_{R}-\mu_{F}\right)-\sum_{j=0}^{N} \int_{\mu_{j+1}}^{\mu_{j}}\left(1-\frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu_{i_{j}}} \mu_{F}\right) d \mu \\
& \leq \epsilon_{R}\left(\mu_{R}-\mu_{F}\right)-\sum_{j=0}^{N} \int_{\mu_{j+1}}^{\mu_{j}}\left(1-\frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu} \mu_{F}\right) d \mu \\
& =\epsilon_{R}\left(\mu_{R}-\mu_{F}\right)-\int_{\mu_{F}}^{\mu_{R}}\left(1-\frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu} \mu_{F}\right) d \mu
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $\epsilon_{R}$ was arbitrary, this proves the claim.
As a result, we can bound the regret in Equation (18) from above:

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) & \leq \alpha\left(\mu_{R}-\mu_{F}-\int_{\mu_{F}}^{\mu_{R}}\left(1-\frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu} \mu_{F}\right) d \mu\right)+(\alpha-1)\left(1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}}{\bar{y}}\right) \mu_{F} \\
& \leq \alpha \int_{\mu_{F}}^{\mu_{R}} \frac{1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}}{\mu} \mu_{F} d \mu+(\alpha-1)\left(1-\frac{\underline{e_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}}{\bar{y}}\right) \mu_{F}
\end{aligned}
$$

Maximizing the right-hand side with respect to $\mu_{F} \leq \mu_{R}$, we obtain

$$
R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}\right) \leq \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)
$$

Combining cases a) and b) concludes the proof of Lemma 5.

# B Proof of Theorem 2 

Fix a regulation $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$.

Proof of point (i). We prove the contrapositive. First, Lemmas 1 to 3 imply that, if $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)<\left(y-\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}\right)\right)^{+}$or $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)>y \wedge \ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}$ for some $0 \leq y<\bar{y}$, then

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C})>\bar{R}
$$

Hence, $\mathcal{C}$ is not optimal.
Lemma 6 deals with the case where $y>\bar{y}$.
Lemma 6. If $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y) \neq \frac{\alpha-1}{2 \alpha-1} y$ for some $y>\bar{y}$, then $\mathcal{C}$ is not optimal.
Proof. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$ be a regulation such that $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)>\frac{\alpha-1}{2 \alpha-1} y^{\prime}$ for some $y^{\prime}>\bar{y}$. We show that $W C R(\mathcal{C})>\bar{R}$.

The proof adapts the argument made in the proof of Lemma 2. Assume that the operational cost $k$ is such that $k<\bar{y}-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{\bar{y}^{\prime}} \bar{y}$. Denote by $B_{i}$ the binary output distribution with support $\left\{0, y^{\prime}\right\}$ and mean $i$. Define the production set $\mathcal{A}^{k}$ as

$$
\mathcal{A}^{k}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right): i \in I=\left[\bar{y} \frac{k}{\bar{y}-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{\bar{y}^{\prime}} \bar{y}}, \bar{y}\right]\right\}
$$

where, for all $i \in I$,

$$
e_{i}=i-\frac{k \bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{\bar{y}^{\prime}} \bar{y}}+k\left(\ln \left(\frac{k \bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{\bar{y}^{\prime}} \bar{y}}\right)-\ln i\right)
$$

By definition of $e_{i}$, for all $w \in \mathcal{C}$,

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial i}\left(\ell^{w} i-e_{i}\right)=\ell^{w}-\frac{i-k}{i} \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow \ell^{w} \geq \frac{i-k}{i}
$$

where $\ell^{w}=\frac{w\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}$. So, $\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ with $i<\bar{y}$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$ if and only if

$$
w\left(y^{\prime}\right)=\frac{i-k}{i} y^{\prime}
$$

while action $i=\bar{y}$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$ if and only if

$$
w\left(y^{\prime}\right) \geq \frac{\bar{y}-k}{\bar{y}} y^{\prime}
$$

Next, observe that, for all $i$, any contract that implements $\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ gives a profit of at most zero to the principal, and exactly zero if the inequality holds with equality. As a result, the contract that implements $\left(e_{\bar{y}}, B_{\bar{y}}\right)$ is the regulator's preferred contract. It maximises the total surplus since $\frac{\partial}{\partial i} e_{i} \leq 1$, and allocates all of it to the worker:

$$
V(\mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(\bar{y}-k-e_{\bar{y}}\right)
$$

However, since no contract gives the firm a strictly positive payoff, taking her outside option maximises her payoff. The regulator's regret is then

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=V(\mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(\bar{y}-k-e_{\bar{y}}\right)
$$

Plugging in the effort cost, the regret is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha\left(\bar{y}-k-e_{\bar{y}}\right) & =\alpha\left(\bar{y}-k-\bar{y}+\frac{k \bar{y}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}-k\left(\ln \left(\frac{k \bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \bar{y}}\right)-\ln \bar{y}\right)\right) \\
& =\alpha k\left(\frac{\bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \bar{y}}-\ln \left(\frac{k}{\bar{y}-\frac{\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \bar{y}}\right)-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

As in the proof of Lemma 2, taking

$$
k=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
e^{\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}}
e^{\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}-1}\left(1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}\right) \bar{y} \text { if } \frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \leq \frac{1}{2} \\
\bar{y}-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \bar{y} \text { if } \frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}>\frac{1}{2}
\end{array}\right.
$$

we get

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C}) \geq R\left(\mathcal{C},\left(k, \mathcal{A}^{k}\right)\right)=\alpha e^{\frac{\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}}{1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}}-1}\left(1-\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}\right) \bar{y} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \leq \frac{1}{2}\right\}}+\alpha \frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}} \bar{y} \mathbb{1}_{\left\{\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}>\frac{1}{2}\right\}}
$$

Since $\frac{w^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}>\frac{\alpha-1}{2 \alpha-1}$ by assumption, the right-hand side is strictly greater than $\bar{R}$. Therefore $\mathcal{C}$ is not optimal.

The proof for the case $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)<\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y$ for some $y \geq \bar{y}$ follows similar steps, by adapting the proof of Lemma 3, and, hence, is omitted.

Proof of point (ii). We prove the contrapositive. Suppose that there exists $w \in \mathcal{C}$ such that $w(\bar{y})=\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}$ and $\underline{\operatorname{conv}}(w)(\bar{y})<\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}$.

If there exists $w \in \mathcal{C}$ such that $w(\bar{y})<\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}$, the result follows from Lemma 3. So, suppose not. The rest of the argument follows from the idea of the proof of Lemma 3. Since $\underline{\operatorname{conv}}(w)(\bar{y})<\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}$, there exists a two point distribution with support on $\left\{y_{1}, y_{2}\right\}$ with $y_{1}<\bar{y}<y_{2}$ such that $p y_{1}+(1-p) y_{2}=\bar{y}$ and $p w\left(y_{1}\right)+(1-p) w\left(y_{2}\right)<\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}$. Let $w^{F} \in \mathcal{C}$ be the contract that minimises

$$
p \tilde{w}\left(y_{1}\right)+(1-p) \tilde{w}\left(y_{2}\right)
$$

Let $\underline{\ell}=\frac{p w^{F}\left(y_{1}\right)+(1-p) w^{F}\left(y_{2}\right)}{\bar{y}}, \underline{\ell}=\frac{\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot \bar{y}}{\bar{y}}$ and observe that $\underline{\ell}<\underline{\ell}$. Finally, let $\mu_{F} \in[0, \bar{y}]$, $\underline{\Pi}=(1-\underline{\ell}) \mu_{F}, \bar{\Pi}=(1-\underline{\ell}) \mu_{F}$, and $\Delta \Pi=\bar{\Pi}-\underline{\Pi}>0$. Define the production set

$$
\mathcal{A}^{\mu_{F}}=\left\{\left(\mathbb{E}_{B_{\mu_{F}}}^{y_{1}, y_{2}}\left[w^{F}(y)\right], B_{\mu_{F}}^{y_{1}, y_{2}}\right)\right\} \cup\left\{\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right): i \in I=\left[\mu_{F}, \bar{y}\right]\right\}
$$

where, for all $i \in I$,

$$
e_{i}=i-\mu_{F}+\Pi(i)\left(\ln \left(\mu_{F}\right)-\ln i\right)+\underline{f} \mu_{F}
$$

where $\Pi:\left[\mu_{F}, \bar{y}\right] \rightarrow[\underline{\Pi}, \bar{\Pi}]$ is a twice differentiable function such that $\Pi(\bar{y})=\bar{\Pi}$, $\Pi\left(\mu_{F}\right)=\underline{\Pi}, \Pi$ is nondecreasing, $\Pi^{\prime}\left(\mu_{F}\right)=\Pi^{\prime}(\bar{y})=0$, and $e_{i}$ is convex. We consider the technology $\mathcal{T}=\left(0, \mathcal{A}^{\mu_{F}}\right)$, i.e., we assume that the firm has no operational cost. For all $0 \leq \mu_{F} \leq \bar{y}$, all outputs' distributions in $\mathcal{A}^{\mu_{F}}$ are supported on $\left\{0, y_{1}, \bar{y}, y_{2}\right\}$. Thus, $\mathcal{A}^{\mu_{F}}$ is compact and satisfies Assumptions 1 and 2.

By definition of $e_{i}$, for all $w \in \mathcal{C}$,

$$
\frac{\partial}{\partial i}\left(\ell^{w} i-e_{i}\right) \geq 0 \Leftrightarrow \ell^{w} \geq \frac{i-\Pi(i)}{i}-\Pi^{\prime}(i)\left(\ln \left(\mu_{F}\right)-\ln (i)\right)
$$

where $\ell^{w}=\frac{w\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{y^{\prime}}$. So, $\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ with $i<\bar{y}$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$ if and only if

$$
w(\bar{y})=\frac{i-\Pi(i)}{i} \bar{y}-\Pi^{\prime}(i)\left(\ln \left(\mu_{F}\right)-\ln (i)\right) \bar{y}
$$

while action $i=\bar{y}$ is implementable by $w \in \mathcal{C}$ if and only if

$$
w(\bar{y}) \geq \frac{\bar{y}-\Pi(\bar{y})}{\bar{y}} \bar{y}
$$

Next, observe that, for all $i$, any contract that implements $\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right)$ gives a profit of at most

$$
\left(1-\frac{i-\Pi(i)}{i}+\Pi^{\prime}(i)\left(\ln \left(\mu_{F}\right)-\ln (i)\right)\right) \mathbb{E}_{B_{i}}[y] \leq \Pi(i)
$$

which is less than $\bar{\Pi}$ for all $i$. Moreover, the contract $w^{F}$ implements both actions $\left(e_{\mu_{F}}, B_{\mu_{F}}^{y_{1}, y_{2}}\right)$ and $\left(e_{\mu_{F}}, B_{\mu_{F}}\right)$. It yields profit $\bar{\Pi}$ in the first case and $\underline{\Pi}$ in the second. In both cases the worker's payoff is zero.

Finally, the contract $w(y)=y$ implements the surplus maximizing action $\left(e_{\bar{y}}, B_{\bar{y}}\right)$

(since $\frac{\partial}{\partial i} e_{i} \leq 1$ ), and leaves no profit to the firm, hence allocating the entire surplus to the worker. So, it is the regulator's preferred contract.

$$
V(\mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(y^{\prime}-e_{y^{\prime}}\right)
$$

The regulator's regret is then

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(\bar{y}-e_{\bar{y}}\right)-\bar{\Pi}
$$

Plugging in the effort cost and the definition of $\bar{\Pi}$, the above is equal to

$$
\begin{aligned}
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}) & =\alpha\left(\mu_{F}-\left(1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}\right) \mu_{F}\left(\ln \left(\mu_{F}\right)-\ln (\bar{y})\right)-\underline{\underline{\ell}} \mu_{F}\right)-(1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}) \mu_{F} \\
& =\alpha(1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}) \mu_{F}+(1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}) \mu_{F}\left(\alpha \ln \left(\frac{\bar{y}}{\mu_{F}}\right)-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the worst-case regret is obtained maximizing over all possible technologies, we can obtain a lower bound by taking $\mu_{F}=\bar{y} e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}-x}$ for some $x>0$. It follows that the regulator's worst-case regret is bounded below by

$$
\begin{aligned}
W C R(\mathcal{C})=\sup _{\mathcal{T}} R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}) & \geq \alpha(1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}) e^{\frac{1}{\alpha}} \bar{y} e^{-x}\left(1+\frac{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}}{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}} x\right) \\
& =\bar{R} e^{-x}\left(1+\frac{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}}{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}} x\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The result then follows if there exists $x>0$ such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{-x}\left(1+\frac{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}}{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}} x\right)>1 \\
\Leftrightarrow & 1+\frac{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}}{1-\underline{\underline{\ell}}} x>e^{x}
\end{aligned}
$$

which holds for $x$ small enough by Taylor's expansion theorem, since $\underline{\underline{\ell}}<\underline{\underline{\ell}}$.
Proof of point (iii). We prove the contrapositive. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$ and suppose that there exists $y \geq \bar{y}$ such that $\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot y, y-\rho^{*}\right] \not \subset \operatorname{Im}(\mathcal{C})(y)$. By Point 1 of Theorem 2, if $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y) \neq$

$\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y$ for some $y \geq \bar{y}, \mathcal{C}$ is not optimal and we are done. So, suppose that $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)=$ $\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y$ for all $y \geq \bar{y}$. Then, there exists $y_{1}, y_{2} \in\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y, y-\rho^{*}\right]$ such that $y_{1}<y_{2}$ and $\left(y_{1}, y_{2}\right) \cap \operatorname{Im}(\mathcal{C})(y)=\emptyset$.

Recall that the technology constructed in Lemma 2 was $\mathcal{T}=\left(k^{\star}, \mathcal{A}^{k^{\star}}\right)$ where

$$
k^{\star}=e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)-y}{y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)}}\left(y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)\right)=\rho^{*}
$$

where the second equality holds since $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)=\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y$, and

$$
\mathcal{A}^{k^{\star}}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right): i \in I=\left[y \frac{k^{\star}}{y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)}, y\right]\right\}
$$

where, for all $i \in I$,

$$
e_{i}=i-\frac{k^{\star} y}{y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)}+k^{\star}\left(\ln \left(\frac{k^{\star} y}{y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)}\right)-\ln i\right)
$$

Under this technology, Lemma 2 shows that the regret is

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=V(\mathcal{T})=\alpha\left(\bar{y}-e_{\bar{y}}-k^{\star}\right)=\alpha e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)-y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}}\left(y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)=\bar{R}
$$

where the last equality holds because $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)=\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y$.
Consider then the modified technology $\tilde{T}=\left(k^{\star}, \tilde{\mathcal{A}}^{k^{\star}}\right)$, where

$$
\mathcal{A}^{k^{\star}}=\left\{\left(\tilde{e}_{i}, B_{i}\right): i \in I=\left[y \frac{k^{\star}}{y-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(y)}, y\right]\right\}
$$

where, for all $i \in I, \tilde{e}_{i}=e_{i}$ if $\frac{i-k^{\star}}{i}<\frac{y_{2}}{y}$ and $\tilde{e}_{i}=e_{i}+\frac{y_{1}}{y}\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)+e_{y_{1}}-e_{y_{2}}$, where $\frac{y_{1}-k^{\star}}{y_{1}}=\ell_{1}$ and $\frac{y_{2}-k^{\star}}{y_{1}}=\frac{y_{2}}{y}=\ell_{2}$. Direct computations yield that $\frac{y_{1}}{y}\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)+e_{y_{1}}-e_{y_{2}}<0$ (or noting that the effort is strictly convex and that $\frac{\partial e_{y_{1}}}{\partial i}=\frac{y_{1}}{y}\left(y_{2}-y_{1}\right)$ ). Moreover, by construction, no productive action yields a positive profit for the firm under $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}$.

Therefore the regulator's regret under $\mathcal{C}$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
R(\mathcal{C}, \tilde{\mathcal{T}}) & =V(\tilde{\mathcal{T}})=\alpha\left(y-\tilde{e}_{y}-k^{*}\right) \\
& =\alpha e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}^{C}\left(y^{\prime}\right)-y^{\prime}}{y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{C}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}}\left(y^{\prime}-\underline{w}^{C}\left(y^{\prime}\right)\right)-\alpha\left(\frac{y_{1}}{y}\left(i_{2}-i_{1}\right)+e_{i_{1}}-e_{i_{2}}\right)>\bar{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

# C Proof of Proposition 1 

By Theorem 1 (ii),

$$
\bar{R}=W C R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{*}\right) \geq \sup _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{T}^{M L R P}} R\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{*}, \mathcal{T}\right)
$$

So, it is enough to show that, for all $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$,

$$
\sup _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{T}^{M L R P}} R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}) \geq \bar{R}
$$

to prove Proposition 1. But, Equation (20) holds if the technologies identified in Lemmas 1 to 3 belong to $\mathbb{T}^{M L R P}$. The technologies considered in Lemma 1 are such that $\# \mathcal{A}=1$. So, they vacuously belong to $\mathbb{T}^{M L R P}$. There remains to show that the technologies considered in Lemmas 2 and 3 also belong to $\mathbb{T}^{M L R P}$. Both cases are similar, so the proof for the latter is omitted.

Recall that the technology constructed in Lemma 2 was $\mathcal{T}=\left(k^{*}, \mathcal{A}^{k^{*}}\right)$ where

$$
k^{*}=e^{\frac{2 \ell_{\alpha}^{*} \underline{q}-\bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \bar{y}}}\left(\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}\right)
$$

and

$$
\mathcal{A}^{k^{*}}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, B_{i}\right): i \in I=\left[\bar{y} \frac{k^{*}}{\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}}, \bar{y}\right]\right\}
$$

where, for all $i \in I$,

$$
e_{i}=i-\frac{k^{*} \bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}}+k^{*}\left(\ln \left(\frac{k^{*} \bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\ell_{\alpha}^{*} \cdot \bar{y}}\right)-\ln i\right)
$$

First, note that $i \geq j \Rightarrow e_{i} \geq e_{j}$, so the effort cost is increasing in $i$. Second, we verify that $i \geq j \Rightarrow B_{i} \geq_{M L R P} B_{j}$ according to Defintion A. 1 in Athey (2002); i.e.,

$$
\frac{d B_{i}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{d C_{i j}\left(y^{\prime}\right)} \frac{d B_{j}(y)}{d C_{i j}(y)} \geq \frac{d B_{j}\left(y^{\prime}\right)}{d C_{i j}\left(y^{\prime}\right)} \frac{d B_{i}(y)}{d C_{i j}(y)}
$$

for all $i \geq j \in I$ and all $y^{\prime} \geq y$ in the support of $\mathcal{C}_{i j}(\cdot)=\frac{1}{2} B_{i}(\cdot)+\frac{1}{2} B_{j}(\cdot)$. By direct calculations, Equation (21) is equivalent to

$$
\frac{i}{\bar{y}}\left(1-\frac{j}{\bar{y}}\right) \geq \frac{j}{\bar{y}}\left(1-\frac{i}{\bar{y}}\right)
$$

which holds since $i \geq j$. So, $i \geq j \Rightarrow B_{i} \geq_{M L R P} B_{j}$ and $\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{T}^{M L R P}$.

# D Online Appendix
## D. 1 Supporting Lemmas for the proof of Theorem 1
## Lemma 7.

1. For any $\alpha \geq 1$ and $\underline{w} \in\left[\frac{1}{2} \bar{y}, \bar{y}\right], \underline{w}>e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w})$.
2. For any $\underline{w} \in\left[0, \frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right], e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w}) \geq \underline{w}$.

Proof. 1. For any $\alpha \geq 1$ and $\underline{w} \in[0, \bar{y}]$,

$$
e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w}) \geq \underline{w} \Longleftrightarrow \underline{w} \leq \frac{e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}}{1+e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}} \bar{y}<\frac{1}{2} \bar{y}
$$

2. Define $f:\left[0, \frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right] \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ by $f(\underline{w})=e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w})-\underline{w}$. Observe that

$$
f\left(\frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right)=e^{2 \frac{\underline{y}-\bar{y}}{g}}\left(\bar{y}-\frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \bar{y}=0
$$

Moreover, $f$ is nonincreasing on its domain, since

$$
\frac{\partial f}{\partial \underline{w}}=\frac{\bar{y}}{\bar{y}-\underline{w}} e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}-e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}-1=\frac{\bar{w}}{\bar{y}-\underline{w}} e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}-1 \leq 0
$$

Therefore, for all $\underline{w} \in\left[0, \frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right]$,

$$
f(\underline{w}) \geq f\left(\frac{1}{2} \bar{y}\right)=0 \Leftrightarrow e^{\frac{2 \underline{w}-\bar{y}}{g-\underline{w}}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w}) \geq \underline{w}
$$

Lemma 8. For all technology $\mathcal{T}$ such that $\Pi(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})>0$, there exists an alternative technology $\mathcal{T}^{0}=\left(k^{0}, \mathcal{A}^{0}\right)$ such that (i) $k^{0}=0$, (ii) the firm optimally offers the contract $\ell_{\alpha}^{\star}$, (iii) the worker's surplus $W S\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right)$ is zero, (iv) $\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right)=\Pi(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})$ and (v)

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}) \leq R\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right)
$$

Proof. Let $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$ and $\mathcal{T}=\left(k, \mathcal{A}=\left\{\left(e_{i}, F_{i}\right)\right\}_{i \in I}\right)$ be a technology such that $\Pi(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})>$ 0 . Define the alternative technology

$$
\mathcal{T}^{0}=\left(k^{0}=0, \mathcal{A}^{0}=\left\{\left(e_{i}^{0}=e_{i}+W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}), F_{i}\right)\right\}_{i \in I}\right)
$$

We claim that $\mathcal{T}^{0}$ satisfies properties (iii)-(v). Property (i) holds by definition: $k^{0}=0$. To see that property (iii) and (iv) are satisfied, note that the firm implements the action $\left(e_{F}^{0}, F_{F}^{0}\right)=\left(e_{F}+W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}), F_{F}\right)$ by offering the same contract $w^{F}$, when solving the profit maximization problem (II) under technology $\mathcal{T}^{0}$. So, $\Pi(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right)$ and $W S\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right)=\mathbb{E}_{F_{F}^{0}}\left[w^{F}(y)\right]-e_{F}^{0}=W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})-W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=0$, and properties (iii) and (iv) hold. Finally, the regulator can offer the contract $w^{R}(y)=y$ in problem $\left(R^{f u l l}\right)$, which induces the worker to take an action that maximises the total surplus. So,

$$
\mu_{R}^{0}-e_{R}^{0} \geq \mu_{R}-e_{R}+W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})
$$

where $\left(e_{R}^{0}, F_{R}^{0}\right)$ is the action implemented by the regulator under complete information under technology $\mathcal{T}^{0}$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right) & =\alpha\left(\mu_{R}^{0}-e_{R}^{0}\right)-\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right) \\
& \geq \alpha\left(\mu_{R}-e_{R}\right)-(\Pi(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})+\alpha W S(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}))-(\alpha-1) k \\
& =R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})
\end{aligned}
$$

So, property (v) holds.
There remains to show that property (ii) holds. If $w^{F}=\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}$, we are done. Otherwise, consider the alternative technology $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}^{0}=\left(0, \mathcal{A}^{0} \cup\left\{\left(\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y^{\star}, \delta_{\left\{y^{\star}\right\}}\right)\right\}\right)$ where $y^{\star}$ solves

$$
\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right)=y^{\star}-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y^{\star}
$$

Offering contract $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}$ implements action $\left(\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y^{\star}, \delta_{\left\{y^{\star}\right\}}\right)$ since

$$
\mathbb{E}_{\delta_{\left\{y^{\star}\right\}}}\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star}(y)\right]-\ell_{\alpha}^{\star}(y)=0=\mathbb{E}_{F_{F}^{0}}\left[w^{F}(y)\right]-e_{F}^{0} \geq \mathbb{E}_{F}\left[w^{F}(y)\right]-e \geq \mathbb{E}_{F}\left[\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y\right]-e
$$

for all $(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}^{0}$. The first inequality follows from the worker incentive compatibility constraint $\left(I C_{W}\right)$ since $w^{F}$ implements $\left(e_{F}^{0}, F_{F}^{0}\right)$, and the second inequality follows from the definition of $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$. Moreover, by definition, implementing action $\left(\ell_{\alpha}^{\star} \cdot y^{\star}, \delta_{\left\{y^{\star}\right\}}\right)$ maximises the firm's profit when her technology is $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}^{0}$ and

$$
\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \tilde{\mathcal{T}}^{0}\right)=\Pi\left(\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}, \tilde{\mathcal{T}}^{0}\right)
$$

So, the profit and worker surplus are the same under regulation $\mathcal{C}_{\alpha}^{\star}$ when the firm's technology is $\mathcal{T}^{0}$ and when the firm's technology is $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}^{0}$. Hence, $R\left(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}^{0}\right)=R\left(\mathcal{C}, \tilde{\mathcal{T}}^{0}\right)$. As a result, technology $\tilde{\mathcal{T}}^{0}$ satisfies properties (i)-(v). This concludes the proof.

Lemma 9. For any $\alpha \geq 1$ and $\underline{w} \in[0, \bar{y}]$, $\alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w}) \geq(\alpha-1)(\bar{y}-\underline{w})$.
Proof. If $\underline{w}=\bar{y}$, this holds as an equality. For any $\underline{w} \in[0, \bar{y})$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}(\bar{y}-\underline{w}) \geq(\alpha-1)(\bar{y}-\underline{w}) & \Longleftrightarrow \alpha e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-(\alpha-1) \geq 0 \\
& \Longleftrightarrow e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-1+\frac{1}{\alpha} \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

Define the function $f(\alpha)=e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-1+\frac{1}{\alpha}$. Then, for $\alpha \neq 0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
f^{\prime}(\alpha) & =\frac{1}{\alpha^{2}}\left(e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-1\right) \leq 0 \\
& \Leftrightarrow e^{-\frac{1}{\alpha}}-1 \leq 0 \\
& \Leftarrow \alpha \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

So, $f$ is decreasing for $\alpha \geq 1$. Furthermore, $f(1)=e^{-1}>0$ and $\lim _{\infty} f=0$. Therefore, $f(\alpha) \geq 0$ for any $\alpha \geq 1$.

# D. 2 Existence of an optimal contract 

Lemma 10. Suppose that either
(i) the regulation $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$ is compact in the topology associated with the product topology on $\mathbb{R}^{\mathbb{R}_{+}}$,
(ii) the regulation $\mathcal{C}$ is convex or
(iii) the regulation $\mathcal{C}$ satisfies the following richness condition: $w \in \mathcal{C} \Rightarrow w \mathbb{1}_{\{y \in A\}}+$ $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}} \mathbb{1}_{\{y \notin A\}} \in \mathcal{C}$ for all Borel set $A \subset \mathbb{R}_{+}$.

Then the regulator's problem under complete information ( $R^{\text {full }}$ ) and the firm's problem (II) admit a solution.

Proof. We prove the existence of a solution to the firm's problem (II). The proof of existence for the regulator's problem ( $R^{\text {full }}$ ) follows the same steps. Hence it is omitted.

Let $\mathcal{T}=(k, \mathcal{A})$ be a technology and $\mathcal{C} \subset \mathcal{C}_{0}$ be a regulation that satisfies condition (i), (ii), or (iii). It is enough to show the existence of a solution to

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T}) & =\sup _{w \in \mathcal{C},(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}} \mathbb{E}_{F}[y-w(y)]-k \\
\text { s.t. } & \mathbb{E}_{F}[w(y)]-e \geq 0 \\
& \mathbb{E}_{F}[w(y)]-e \geq \mathbb{E}_{\tilde{F}}[w(y)]-\tilde{e}, \text { for all }(\tilde{e}, \tilde{F}) \in \mathcal{A}
\end{aligned}
$$

Consider a maximizing sequence $\left(w_{n},\left(e_{n}, F_{n}\right)\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$. The value of the above program, $P(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})$, is finite by Assumption 1. So, there exists $N \in \mathbb{N}$ such that, for all $n \geq N$,

$$
\int w_{n}(y) d F_{n}(y)<\sup _{(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}} \mathbb{E}_{F}[y]-\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})+1
$$

Relabelling if necessary, we can assume that $N=1$. Moreover, since $w_{n}$ implements

$\left(e_{n}, F_{n}\right)$, the incentive compatibility constraint implies that, for all $(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}$,

$$
\int w_{n}(y) d F(y) \leq \int w_{n}(y) d F_{n}(y)+e-e_{n} \leq \sup _{(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}}\left\{\mathbb{E}_{F}[y]\right\}-\mathcal{P}(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})+1+\sup _{(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}}\left\{e-e_{n}\right\}
$$

So, by Assumption 1, there exists a constant $K>0$ such that

$$
\sup _{n \in \mathbb{N}} \sup _{(e, F)} \int w_{n}(y) d F(y)<K<\infty
$$

Moreover, since $\mathcal{A}$ is compact in the topology associated with the total variation norm by Assumption 1, there exists a finite dominating measure $\nu$ on $\mathbb{R}_{+}$such that, for all $n \in \mathbb{N}, F_{n}<<\nu$ by Theorem 4.6.3 in Bogachev (2007). The compactness of $\mathcal{A}$ also implies that, passing to a subsequence if necessary, $\left(e_{n}, F_{n}\right) \rightarrow\left(e^{*}, F^{*}\right) \in \mathcal{A}$, and, thus, that $\frac{d F_{n}}{d \nu} \rightarrow \frac{d F^{*}}{d \nu}$ in $L^{1}(\nu)$. Passing again to a subsequence if necessary, we can finally assume that $\frac{d F_{n}}{d \nu} \rightarrow \frac{d F^{*}}{d \nu} \nu$-almost surely.

If $\mathcal{C}$ is compact, then there exists a subsequence of $\left(w_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ that converges to some $w^{\star} \in \mathcal{C}$. Otherwise, by the Dunford-Pettis Theorem (Theorem 4.7.18 in Bogachev (2007)) and (22), there exists a subsequence of $\left(w_{n}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ that converges weakly in $L^{1}\left(F^{*}\right)$ to some $w^{\star}$. (22) implies that we can invoke Komlós' Subsequence Theorem (Theorem 4.7.24 in Bogachev (2007)). Therefore, there exists a further subsequence such that every subsubsequences Césaro converges to $w^{\star} F^{\star}$-almost surely. Since $\mathcal{A}$, is compact, by a diagonal argument, we can extract a further subsequence such that every subsubsequences Césaro converges $\nu$-almost surely to $w^{\star}$ invoking again Komlós' Theorem.

Finally, our richness conditions (ii) or (iii) guarantees that either $w^{\star} \in \mathcal{C}$ (if $\mathcal{C}$ is convex) or that we can modify $w^{\star}$ so that it is equal to $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}$ on $d \nu<<0$ without affecting the $\nu$-almost sure convergence. Then, the modified version of $w^{\star}$ belongs to $\mathcal{C}$.

Summarizing, we can choose the maximizing sequence $\left(w_{n},\left(e_{n}, F_{n}\right)\right)$ such that it converges to some $\left(w^{\star},\left(e^{\star}, F^{\star}\right)\right) \in \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{A}$, where the $w_{n}{ }^{\prime}$ s convergence is understood

to be Césaro $\nu$-almost surely and the $F_{n}$ 's convergence is understood to be the $\nu$ almost sure convergence of their Radon-Nykodym derivatives.

We are now ready to prove that $\left(w^{\star},\left(e^{\star}, F^{\star}\right)\right)$ maximises $(P)$. We first show that $w^{\star}$ implements $\left(e^{\star}, F^{\star}\right)$. Observe that

$$
\left(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i}(y)}{n}\right) \frac{d F_{n}(y)}{d \nu} \rightarrow w^{\star}(y) \frac{d F^{\star}(y)}{d \nu}, \quad \nu \text {-almost surely. }
$$

Equation (22) and Vitali's convergence Theorem (Theorem 4.5.4 in Bogachev (2007)) then implies that, for all $(e, F)$,

$$
\int \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i}(y)}{n} d F(y) \rightarrow \int w^{\star}(y) d F(y) \text { and } \int\left(\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i}(y)}{n}\right) d F_{n}(y) \rightarrow \int w^{\star}(y) d F^{\star}(y)
$$

It follows that

$$
\int w^{\star}(y) d F^{\star}(y)-e^{\star} \geq \max \left\{\int w^{\star}(y) d F(y)-e, 0\right\} \text { for all }(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}
$$

Therefore $w^{\star}$ implements $\left(e^{\star}, F^{\star}\right)$. To conclude, there remains to show that

$$
\int\left(y-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i}(y)}{n}\right) d F_{n}(y) \rightarrow \int\left(y-w^{\star}(y)\right) d F^{\star}(y)
$$

This again follows from Vitali convergence theorem since the sequence

$$
\left(\left(y-\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} w_{i}(y)}{n}\right) \frac{d F_{n}(y)}{d \nu}\right)_{n \in \mathbb{N}}
$$

is uniformly bounded by (22) and converges $\nu$-almost surely to $\left(y-w^{\star}(y)\right) \frac{d F^{\star}(y)}{d \nu}$.

# D. 3 Proof of Proposition 2 

We first show that no regulation can achieve a regret smaller than $\underline{R}$.
Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a regulation unconstrained by limited liability. Suppose that the production set $\mathcal{A}$ contains a single action: $\mathcal{A}=\left\{\left(0, \delta_{\{\bar{y}\}}\right)\right\}$. Let $0 \leq k<\bar{y}$. The technology

$\mathcal{T}=(k, \mathcal{A})$ satisfies Assumptions 1 and 2 . Under the regulation $\mathcal{C}$, the maximal profit the firm can obtain is

$$
\bar{y}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})-k
$$

If $k>\bar{y}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})$, no contract is signed between the firm and the worker, as the firm strictly prefers her outside option to the best available contract in $\mathcal{C}$. The regret for the regulator is then

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=\alpha(\bar{y}-k)
$$

Maximizing over $k \in\left[0, \bar{y}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y}) \vee 0\right)$, we obtain

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C}) \geq \alpha \underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y}) \vee 0
$$

Next, suppose that the production set $\mathcal{A}$ contains a single action $\mathcal{A}=\left\{\left(0, \delta_{\{\bar{y}}\right)\right\}$, and that the operational cost is $k=0$. The technology $\mathcal{T}=(0, \mathcal{A})$ satisfies Assumptions 1 and 2 . Under the regulation $\mathcal{C}$, the firm's profit is bounded above

$$
\Pi(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=\bar{y}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})
$$

The associated worker's surplus is $\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})$ if the firm produces. On the other hand, the regulator would grant the entire surplus to the worker. The regulator's regret is therefore

$$
R(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{T})=(\alpha-1)\left(\bar{y}-\underline{w}^{\mathcal{C}}(\bar{y})\right)
$$

Summarizing, for all regulations $\mathcal{C}$ unconstrained by limited liability,

$$
W C R(\mathcal{C}) \geq \min _{0 \leq \underline{w} \leq \bar{y}} \max \left\{\alpha \underline{w},(\alpha-1)(\bar{y}-\underline{w})\right\}=\underline{R}
$$

Second, we prove that the regulation $\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}=\left\{w: \mathbb{R}_{+} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}: w(y)=y-S\right.$ with $\left.S \leq \frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}\right\}$ is optimal. To do so, it is enough to show that the regulation $\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}$ achieves the uniform lower bound on regret we computed above:

$$
W C R\left(\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}\right)=\underline{R}
$$

Let $\mathcal{T}=(k, \mathcal{A}) \in \mathbb{T}$ be a technology, and assume that $V(\mathcal{T})>0$ (otherwise, the regret is 0 ). Define

$$
P\left(\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}, \mathcal{T}\right)=\max _{w \in \mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }},(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}} \mathbb{E}_{F}[y-w(y)]
$$

subject to $\left(I R_{W}\right)$ and $\left(I C_{W}\right)$. Distinguish two cases:

1. $k \geq P\left(\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}, \mathcal{T}\right)$, and
2. $k \leq P\left(\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}, \mathcal{T}\right)$.
3. Suppose that $k \geq P\left(\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}, \mathcal{T}\right)$. Then the firm opts not too produce and, for all $w \in \mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}$ that implements some action $\left(e^{w}, F^{w}\right) \in \mathcal{A}$,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{F^{w}}[y-w(y)] \leq k
$$

Denote the efficient action by $(\bar{e}, \bar{F}) \in \arg \max _{(e, F) \in \mathcal{A}}\left\{\mathbb{E}_{F}[y]-e-k\right\}$.
Claim: $k \geq \frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}$.
Proof of the Claim: Suppose for a contradiction that $k<\frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}$. Then, the firm can offer the contract $w(y)=y-k-\epsilon$, which belongs to $\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}$ for $\epsilon>0$ small enough. A best response by the worker is to choose $(\bar{e}, \bar{F})$, which gives him a payoff of

$$
\mathbb{E}_{F}[y-k]-\bar{e}-\epsilon>0
$$

for $\epsilon>0$ small enough, since $V(\mathcal{T})>0$. Therefore, there exists $w \in \mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}$ that gives a strictly positive profit to the firm, which contradicts $k \geq P\left(\mathcal{C}^{\text {noLL }}, \mathcal{T}\right)$.

Thus, $k \geq \frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}$, and

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right) & =V(\mathcal{T}) \\
& =\alpha\left(\mathbb{E}_{\bar{F}}[y]-\bar{e}-k\right) \\
& \leq \alpha\left(\mathbb{E}_{\bar{F}}[y]-\frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}\right) \\
& \leq \alpha \frac{\alpha-1}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y} \\
& =\underline{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

2. Observe that all $w \in \mathcal{C}^{n o L L}$ implement an efficient action. Denote by $(\bar{e}, \bar{F})$ the efficient action optimally implemented by the firm, and not that we can always assume that the regulator implements the same action. The regulator's regret is therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right) & =V(\mathcal{T})-\left(P\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right)-k+\alpha W S\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right)\right) \\
& =(\alpha-1)\left(P\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right)-k\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Since for all $y \geq 0$ and $w \in \mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, y-w(y) \leq \frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}$,

$$
P\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right) \leq \frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}
$$

Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right) & =(\alpha-1)\left(P\left(\mathcal{C}^{n o L L}, \mathcal{T}\right)-k\right) \\
& \leq(\alpha-1)\left(\frac{\alpha}{2 \alpha-1} \bar{y}-k\right) \\
& \leq \underline{R}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since the above holds for an arbitrary technology $\mathcal{T} \in \mathbb{T}, \mathcal{C}^{n o L L}$ is optimal. This concludes the proof.

abstract:
We study the robust regulation of labour contracts in moral hazard problems.
A firm offers a contract to incentivise a worker protected by limited
liability. A regulator chooses the set of permissible contracts to (i) improve
efficiency and (ii) protect the worker. The regulator does not know the
worker's actions and the firm's costs and evaluates regulations by their
worst-case regret. The regret-minimising regulation imposes a minimum piece
rate compensation for the worker: it allows all contracts above a minimum
linear contract. The slope of the minimum contract balances the worker's
protection and the necessary flexibility for incentive provision.
